results.title: The Lost singing = Shi qu de ge sheng
results.creator_credit: Shi Wei and Tianjin Film Studio
results.brief_description:
This film is about the impact of divorce families on kids. Liang Lili is a Year 4 student and has an excellent singing voice. She is selected for a competition by the Art Troupe of the Children’s Palace. Lili is excited to share the good news with her parents. But what awaits at home is her parents’ quarrelling. Lili’s dad moved out, Lili’s mum couldn’t cheer up, and Lili’s study was affected. One day, Lili saw her father with another woman and realized that the worst would happen. Her parents divorced and the smile in Lili’s face was gone. Lili’s mum relocated to another city and Lili’s dad moved back with the lady and her son. Lili hates the new “mum” and the “little brother”, who broke her piggy bank. The “hatred” between Lili and her new brother escalated, which worried their parents. One night, Lili and her brother were both lonely, each missing their own separated parent. The two kids started to feel sympathetic with each other as both suffered the same. In order to help her brother to go back to see his father, Lili saved money to buy a ticket for him. The two kids said good bye at the train station, and Lili decided to go and look for her mum.

Directed by a female director, the film shows that family melodrama is a recurring theme in Chinese cinema. Director Shi Wei began her career as an actress and acted in films such as Tracks in the Snowy Forrest, an extremely popular film of the 1960s.
Tianjin Film Studio was established in 1958.
The significance of the film lies in that it dealt with a less-discussed topic as divorce was very uncommon in the early 1980s in China. Not much background information about the film could be found. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: The Lost pharaoh: the search for Akhenaten
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Kendall, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The fascinating story of an ancient Pharaoh and the archaeological sleuthing which went into piecing together information about his life. An accidental discovery in 1975 by Canadian archaeologist Dr. Donald Redford and his team led to the uncovering of the foundation of one of Akhenaten’s temples. Commentary and narration by Donald Brittain.

results.title: The Lost James Brown tapes
results.creator_credit: Alan Douglas, Chris Mould and Gravity
results.brief_description: Exciting live concert footage of the master of funk and godfather of soul, the inimitable James Brown. Supposedly shot in Monterey, California in 1979, this live concert shows the master in fine form. His powerful voice and trademark dance moves don’t disappoint but the transition to DVD format is a little dubious (may have been shot off a television screen). The ten songs featured are: “Get up offa that thing”, “Body heat”, “Try me”, “Sex machine”, “Georgia on my mind”, “Please please please”, “Hindsight”, “Can’t stand it”, “Papa’s got a brand new bag” and “Jam”. Original producers of the live concert footage were Eric Therman, Rod Crowe and Robert Sheridan. The title listed on the cover (as opposed to the actual work) is “James Brown: Body Heat Live”.

results.title: The Lost generation
results.creator_credit: Brian Nicholls and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
Keith Windschuttle, looks at the problems of high youth unemployment as manifested in the increasing numbers of young homeless people squatting in derelict houses. Suggests that more innovations in secondary education would help prepare students for the realities of the present job market.

results.title: The Lost boys (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Harvey Bernhard and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This popular 1987 film presents an interesting mix of genres: the 1980s teen movie with vampires. Michael and Sam are two brothers who have moved with their mother to Santa Carla, “murder capitol of the world”, unaware of the vampires residing in this fictional Californian Coastal town (the film was shot in Santa Barbara, and includes spectacular footage of the Boardwalk and beach-side amusement park). Michael is charmed by a girl named Star, and immediately falls in with a tough young gang led by David. It’s peer pressure in the extreme as Michael is tricked into drinking blood. He is turned into an unwilling vampire, and Sam looks to a pair of comic book vendors who are well versed in the dealings with vampires, to help save Michael. The insecurities and frustrations of youth are amplified and satirised by this exciting and funny MTV-generation thriller. Cast includes: Jason Patric, Corey Haim, Dianne Wiest, Kiefer Sutherland and Corey Feldman.

results.title: The Lost babies
results.brief_description: A documentary about the tragedy of babies who are either stillborn or who die very soon after birth and the emotional consequences for the parents. Parents who have experienced the death of their baby discuss their reactions and specialists talk about how they can help the parents through the grieving process.

results.title: The Lost 600
results.creator_credit: Michael Robertson, New South Wales. Dept. of Sport and Recreation and Michael Robertson Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safety in, on and near the water”.
Emphasises the dangers associated with foolish, unsafe and reckless behaviour in and on the water. Among the many aspects of water safety covered are still-water drownings, surf safety, boating, yachting, water skiing, rock fishing and home pools.

results.title: The Lorne Theatre
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Established over 90 years ago, the Lorne Theatre came about when a travelling picture show man ran out of funds and some local business men purchased his equipment and started running movies in the local hall. It then moved to its present site in 1937, where for such a small permanent population, the theatre has not changed much in all those years. Tony Hill, Manager of the Lorne Theatre, talks about the difficulties in offering a diverse range of cinema in the climate of DVDs and downloadable movies, and operating in a town prone to blackouts. He is proud the theatre is attended by a local group of cinephiles who sit in the same seat every session, and thinks himself very lucky to have his job.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the two towers special extended edition [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Barrie M Osborne and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: The fight between good and evil is played out using spectacular locations and stupendous special effects in “The Two Towers”, the second instalment of Peter Jackson’s iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings”. Middle Earth is now on the brink of a vicious war, and its fate rests on the shoulders of the ‘Fellowship’, now separated into three groups. Pulled by the ring’s power, Frodo heads towards Mount Doom with Sam, only to encounter an unlikely guide; Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli head towards Rohan; and Merry and Pippin find an ally in the terrifying Fangorn Forest. While this film culminates in two spectacular battles between the humans of Helm’s Deep and Saruman’s vicious minions and Saruman and the Ents, the tale twists and turns around numerous subplots and many new characters, including the twisted half-hobbit Gollum, a warped creature who will do anything to regain what he believes is rightfully his. Once again, Jackson and his screenwriters successfully reproduce a classic tale, which, unlike a number of blockbuster sequels, equals if not surpasses its predecessor, both enthralling and teasing the audience as the tale continues. Cast includes Elijah Wood, Sean Astin, Dominic Monaghan, Billy Boyd, John Rhys-Davies, Viggo Mortensen, Orlando Bloom, Christopher Lee, Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler, Hugo Weaving, Brad Dourif, Miranda Otto, Karl Urban, Bernard Hill, David Wenham and Andy Serkis as the voice of Gollum.
